means that you have 3 samples/observations and each is characterised by 2 features/variables (2 dimensional).

```
from sklearn import datasets
from sklearn import linear_model

# import some data to play with
iris = datasets.load_iris()
X = iris.data[:, :1]  # we only take the feature
y = iris.target

clf = linear_model.Lasso(alpha=0.1)

clf.fit(X,y)

print(clf.coef_)
print(clf.intercept_)
```

    def add_zeros(item: str) -> str:
        nums = item.split(":")
        formatted_item = ":".join(f"{int(num):02d}" for num in nums)

answers.title: How to add zero to single digit number(time)?

answers.body_markdown:
You could use [string formatting][1] to pad zeros to strings, e.g. to pad to the left:

    >>> nums = ['10:30', '9:30', '11:0']
    >>> ['{:0>2}:{:0>2}'.format(*n.split(':')) for n in nums]
    ['10:30', '09:30', '11:00']

Alternatively, converting strings to numbers:

    >>> ['{:02d}:{:02d}'.format(*map(int, n.split(':'))) for n in nums]
    ['10:30', '09:30', '11:00']

  [1]: https://docs.python.org/3/library/string.html#formatspec
answers.title: How to add zero to single digit number(time)?

answers.body_markdown:
Here's a solution utilizing `zfill` & `ljust`
```
nums = ["10:30", "9:30", "11:0"]

fixed = []
for t in nums:
    x, y = t.split(':')
    fixed.append(x.zfill(2) + ':' + y.ljust(2, '0'))

print(fixed)
```

You could also manually enable such option in the VS on your build agent.

Also find a [link][1] mentioned it seems also work with Msbuild arguments. Even not documented anywhere in Msbuild command doc. I wonder whether IntelliTrace is still running even though it's not explicitly specified to do so

[![enter image description here][2]][2]


----------


However, looks like you just want to find the root cause why your tests failed on tfs build even it passed locally. 

To narrow down the issue, suggest you **directly remote to your build agent**. Instead of through TFS build, manually build your project, run the tests in the Visual Studio on build agent. 

It will come out whether it's an environment issue. You must make sure it's the same environment for build agent and your local. 

TFS is just using **build service account** to invoke msbuild/vstest  command in build agent to run build/test.

Also make sure build service account have appropriately permission if your tests required  some permission.

Consider the following code:

```Scala
df = dataframe.cache() // <--- Lazy
ParSeq(df.transform(a), df.transform(b)).foreach { 
   // Materialize here
}
```
In the above example the `cache` will be evaluated twice by two threads in a race condition. My specific questions are:

1. Is Spark smart enough to wait for one of the treads to build the cache and then share the cache?
2. How many cached instances do we end up with?
3. Is the process deterministic?
4. Is this documented somewhere?

At a high level, you can only do three things to resolve that error:

* Refactor the schema so that the `size` field is the same type for both types.
* Alias one or both fields.
* Only request the field for one of the types.

If you need to pass the response to another API, the easiest thing would be to use aliases and then transform the response client-side before sending it to the API.

answers.body_markdown:
For security management with REST APIs you can refer to [Security][1] for details. Some of the REST APIs are not documented, however we can track them by develop tools (the simplest way is pressing F12 in your browser).

In your scenario seems you are trying to manage the permission of the pipelines in a specific project. If so, we can navigate to the **Pipeline** node -> **Manage security** -> Select the specific group/user to set the permission accordingly, (Just track the APIs when do the actions).

To run the pipelines, we at least need the `View build pipeline` , `View builds`, `Queue builds` permissions. You can also set other permissions as needed.

For example, just **Deny** the `Queue builds` permission for the **Contributors** group:

    POST https://dev.azure.com/{organization}/{Project}/_api/_security/ManagePermissions?api-version=5.1
    
    Sample Request Body:
    {"updatePackage":"{\"IsRemovingIdentity\":false,\"TeamFoundationId\":\"24cb2a78-4d79-49d6-b96c-bf0ac65d7032\",\"DescriptorIdentityType\":\"Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Identity\",\"DescriptorIdentifier\":\"S-1-9-1551374245-3809964236-1275365961-2582801090-4223875273-1-492339072-1927234371-3142690236-612141869\",\"PermissionSetId\":\"33344d9c-fc72-4d6f-aba5-fa317101a7e9\",\"PermissionSetToken\":\"cc7017e3-044c-498a-99f2-6ac2fbc338c9\",\"RefreshIdentities\":false,\"Updates\":[{\"PermissionId\":2,\"PermissionBit\":128,\"NamespaceId\":\"33344d9c-fc72-4d6f-aba5-fa317101a7e9\",\"Token\":\"cc7017e3-044c-498a-99f2-6ac2fbc338c9\"}],\"TokenDisplayName\":null}"}

Do the same things to track the APIs to manage the variable groups.

In addition, you can also use the Azure CLI to manage the permissions, refer to [az devops security][2] for details.

[![enter image description here][3]][3]


  [1]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/azure/devops/security/?view=azure-devops-rest-5.1
  [2]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/devops/security?view=azure-cli-latest
  [3]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/zIWRt.png

answers.body_markdown:
Short version: The CP subsystem has a session mechanism that keeps track of the liveness of all members.   When it recognizes the member holding the lock has died, the lock will be released.  The session heartbeat mechanism can be tuned if needed to meet the performance needs of the specific application. 

Long version:  I'd suggest reading this blog post:
 https://hazelcast.com/blog/long-live-distributed-locks/
and in particular, the section 'what happens if a lock holder dies'. 

One of the trickier aspects of making this type of code reliable is what happens when there is a network problem ... for example, the lock holder may go offline, and heartbeats won't be seen.  So the cluster declares the lock holder dead, releases the lock, and assigns it to someone else.   Then the lock holder comes back online and tries to continue processing, thinking it still has the lock.  The FencedLock implementation within Hazelcast will recognize the lock as stale and not allow the holder of the stale lock to proceed - he must re-acquire the lock before taking any action covered by the lock.
answers.title: Hazelcast lock - instance death

answers.body_markdown:
I tested my Auto-Update using an Internal Test Track, and what I did was open the Google Play App Store on the AVD emulator I was testing on, open to my App's Page.  I downloaded the first test build from the internal test track onto the emulator through the Google Play App on the emulator to set up the test the first time.  Then, whenever I uploaded another build to the internal test track, I would refresh the app page in the Google Play App on the emulator until I saw the new build number was available - which was pretty soon after I uploaded it, then, I ran my tests.  So, it shouldn't take days.  The App Store on the device should recognize if you are running a build from the internal test track if you've done this, and it should show the new internal test track build on the App Store app on the AVD almost immediately.

Though, it's pretty easy to get the App Store confused, and it might be checking your published app version instead of your internal test track version if you go back and forth with different versions on the device you are testing on.

I also found that the FLEXIBLE update was more glitchy than the IMMEDIATE update, and so, have stuck with that for production.
answers.title: Why does In-App update fail with resultCode 0?

The answer to this problem is already inside the question itself. As the cookies are HttpOnly cookies, the browser can't track their existence - nevertheless they are still existing. This is actually the reason the HttpOnly flag was created for.

For testing purposes it might be a better approach to test the functionality the cookies should provide instead of simply checking their existence.

I ran the Chrome WebDriver tests without a docker-compose, which I did in the CI-pipeline. That is why the browser was not able to see the HttpOnly cookies.

While creating an invoice through  YV60SBAT-SDBILLDL via job - we have to do some checks.
If some of these custom checks don't pass, we should restrict the system not to create an invoice for that particular document and should continue for the rest of the documents. Also, that error message should be displayed in batch job log..

Here is an example:

Delivery documents: say 1,2,3

1-Invoice should generate

answers.body_markdown:
You can use `gregexpr` to test if `2020` appears twice:
```
length(gregexpr("2020", "DataMW_2029__ForecastMW_2020")[[1]]) == 2
#[1] FALSE

length(gregexpr("2020", "DataMW_2020__ForecastMW_2020")[[1]]) == 2
#[1] TRUE
```
Or with a `regex` testing for 2 and more.
```
grepl("(.*2020){2}", "DataMW_2029__ForecastMW_2020")
#[1] FALSE

grepl("(.*2020){2}", "DataMW_2020__ForecastMW_2020")
#[1] TRUE
```
or for exact 2 hits:
```
grepl("^(?!(.*2020){3})(.*2020){2}.*$", "DataMW_2029__ForecastMW_2020", perl=TRUE)
#[1] FALSE
grepl("^(?!(.*2020){3})(.*2020){2}.*$", "DataMW_2020__ForecastMW_2020", perl=TRUE)
#[1] TRUE
grepl("^(?!(.*2020){3})(.*2020){2}.*$", "DataMW_2020__ForecastMW_2020_2020", perl=TRUE)
#[1] FALSE
```

answers.body_markdown:
Try the following pattern:

    ^\/(app[AB])(?!\/download).*

It uses a [negative lookahead](https://www.regextester.com/94366) to check against `download`.

You can see it demo'd [at https://regexr.com/4mqah](https://regexr.com/4mqah).
answers.title: Match URL Paths A+ or B+ but not AX+

answers.body_markdown:
I believe what you need is a negative look ahead. In regex: `(?!<pattern>)`

Your regex should be able to match the full string using this method (using `^` and `$`) like so:
```
(^\/(appA|appB))(?!\/download).*$
```
The Negative look ahead: `(?!\/download)` will exclude matches where `"/download"` follows right after `/appA` or `/appB`

Note: The `.*` is going to match the rest of the string (ex: `/something` in `/appA/something`) but is optional so `/appA` still is a valid match. 

Here is a RegexR to show the examples: [RegexR -  (^\/(appA|appB))(?!\/download).*$](https://regexr.com/4mqaq)
answers.title: Match URL Paths A+ or B+ but not AX+

**Context:**  

We have a Visual Studio project that depends on a nuget package (A Visual Studio thing). 

We upgrade our project with that nuget package every time we release a new version of that package.

The project is stored in git and we clone the project to get a local copy so we can start the upgrade from Visual Studio itself through nuget updates.

A colleague complained/noticed that the upgrade would take about 30 or so minutes, and it started off the question of why it was so slow.

We then all did the same and sure enough it was roughly 10 minutes faster.

As a mitigation we have been copying the project into another folder thus not having git whizzing away in the background, and once the project has finished uploading, we put the project back into the original folder and then git picks up on the changes made in one big hit.

**NB**

I write this from an uncertain stand point. Okay, removing git makes it faster, but of course, i am unsure of what really is happening under the hood... so the question may be a bit moot in terms of git. But if we can figure it out, across the company it would save so much time!

answers.body_markdown:
There are many ways to achieve this :

**VNet Integration**

A Standard, Premium, or Isolate app service plan offers the ability for an app service to connect with a virtual network via a point-to-site VPN. The virtual network must have a VPN gateway that is Basic/Dynamic, VpnGw1 or a higher size, and configure for point-to-site connectivity.

[![enter image description here][1]][1]

Once an app service is connected to a virtual network, you can:

Enable the app service to talk with Azure virtual machines on that virtual network.
Hop to on-premises via site-to-site VPN connections also make by that gateway.
The point-to-site VPN connection inherits the SLA of the gateway in question. There are some limitations:

The connection speed is limited to what the gateway can offer (80-100Mpbs using the Basic size gateway).
An app service plan can support connections to just 5 virtual networks.
An app service can connect to just one virtual network.




**Hybrid Connection**

This is a feature that I really like and in conversations that Iâ€™ve had, it seems to be an approach that few are aware of. However, it has been available for years in the Basic, Standard, and Premium plans.

[![enter image description here][2]][2]




**Azure Service Environment (ASE)**

The ASE is a solution where you deploy one or more single-tenant Isolated tier app services plans in an environment that is connected to a virtual network. This means that every instance in the app service plan is already in the virtual network, and can communicate directly with Azure virtual machines in the same network without needing any VPN or hybrid connections.

An internal ASE, deployed using an internal load balancer presents your Isolated tier app services to users/systems via a single private IP address. You can route to that private IP address in a number of ways:

A web application gateway
Third-party firewall appliances (virtual machines) in a front-end subnet
From remote or on-premises networks using a site-to-site VPN or ExpressRoute connection

[![enter image description here][3]][3]


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/SVbO6.png
  [2]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/SWq3Q.png
  [3]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/kPshf.png

answers.title: Checking if values â€‹exist within string

answers.body_markdown:
You can use `TRANSLATE` to test for the first condition and the other two are simple tests for equality:

```sql
SELECT *
FROM   your_table
WHERE  token = 'Oracle Database Token: -.'
OR     token = 'Oracle Database Token: 123456789.'
OR     (   token <> 'Oracle Database Token: .'
       AND TRANSLATE( token, '_1', '_' ) = 'Oracle Database Token: .' )
```

**Sample Data**:

```
CREATE TABLE your_table ( token ) AS
  SELECT 'Oracle Database Token: -.' FROM DUAL UNION ALL
  SELECT 'Oracle Database Token: 123456789.' FROM DUAL UNION ALL
  SELECT 'Oracle Database Token: 1.' FROM DUAL UNION ALL
  SELECT 'Oracle Database Token: 111.' FROM DUAL UNION ALL
  SELECT 'Oracle Database Token: 111111.' FROM DUAL UNION ALL
  SELECT 'Oracle Database Token: 12111.' FROM DUAL UNION ALL
  SELECT 'Oracle Database Token: -12.' FROM DUAL;
```

**Query Output**:

> <pre>
> | TOKEN                             |
> | :-------------------------------- |
> | Oracle Database Token: -.         |
> | Oracle Database Token: 123456789. |
> | Oracle Database Token: 1.         |
> | Oracle Database Token: 111.       |
> | Oracle Database Token: 111111.    |
> </pre>

*db<>fiddle [here](https://dbfiddle.uk/?rdbms=oracle_18&fiddle=ee04e29b14a42884263c98660eeb72d1)*

-----------------

You could also write it as a regular expression:

```sql
SELECT *
FROM   your_table
WHERE  REGEXP_LIKE( token, '^Oracle Database Token: (1+|123456789|-)\.$' )
```

But simple string functions/comparisons might be quicker.

answers.body_markdown:
Seems like we could use use an inline view on `gp_citation`. The inline view query can contain the `DISTINCT` keyword in the SELECT list, or can use a `GROUP BY` function and aggregates.

It's not clear from the information provided which "duplicates" are to be eliminated.

Leaving the inline view `pub` as is, we can do a join to an inline view:

     SELECT pub.*
          , cit.*
       FROM ( SELECT p.id
                   , p.collection_id
                   , p.year
                   , p.collection_name
                   , p.collection_volume
                   , p.collection_number
                   , p.title
                   , p.is_international_relations
                   , p.is_book_review
                   , p.gp_status
                FROM gp_publication p
               WHERE p.collection_id IN (1304,577,387,19,5739,6245,6246,6522,6524,6526,6527,6528,6529,6530,6531,150,6525)
                 AND p.year                      >= 2011 
                 AND p.year                      <= 2015
                 AND p.is_international_relations = 1
                 AND p.is_book_review             = 0
            ) pub
       JOIN ( SELECT c.cited_article_id
                   , c.citing_article_id
                FROM gp_citation c
               GROUP
                  BY c.cited_article_id
                   , c.citing_article_id
            ) cit
         ON cit.citing_article_id = pub.id
      ORDER
         BY ...



My expectation is that an article could be "cited" by several other articles ... that is, there could be multiple rows in `gp_citation` with the same `cited_article_id` and a variety of `citing_article_id`.

If the goal is to avoid returning "duplicate" rows for `gp_publication`, assuming `id` is a unique identifier, we could do somthing like this:


     SELECT pub.id
          , pub.collection_id
          , pub.year
          , pub.collection_name
          , pub.collection_volume
          , pub.collection_number
          , pub.title
          , pub.is_international_relations
          , pub.is_book_review
          , pub.gp_status
       FROM ( SELECT p.id AS pub_id
                FROM ( SELECT c.cited_article_id
                            , c.citing_article_id
                         FROM gp_citation cit
                        GROUP
                           BY c.cited_article_id
                            , c.citing_article_id
                     ) cit
                JOIN gp_publication p
                  ON p.id = cit.citing_article_id
               WHERE p.collection_id IN (1304,577,387,19,5739,6245,6246,6522,6524,6526,6527,6528,6529,6530,6531,150,6525)
                 AND p.year                      >= 2011 
                 AND p.year                      <= 2015
                 AND p.is_international_relations = 1
                 AND p.is_book_review             = 0
               GROUP
                  BY p.id
            ) cc
       JOIN gp_publication pub
         ON pub.id = cc.pub_id
      ORDER
         BY ...

Multiple Parallel Function Execution

answers.body_markdown:
Just keep in mind that all your inserts need to happen within the same transaction. Moreover, if you are reading id from the reference table, you need to take exclusive lock before reading in order to avoid duplicates in reference table. E.g., assuming TR to be transaction table and REF to be reference table, where TR has a foreign key pointing to REF, your code needs to do something like this:

```
begin tran
declare @ref_id int
sp_getapplock 'REF' + @x, 'Exclusive'
-- please note that xlock will not help if row doesn't exist
select @ref_id = id from REF where x = @x
if @@rowcount = 0
begin
    insert REF(x) values(@x)
    set @ref_id = scope_identity()
end
sp_releaseapplock 'REF' + @x
insert TR(ref_id, other_fields) values(@ref_id, @other_fields)
commit
```

answers.body_markdown:
You cannot decrypt hashes. They aren't encryptions. Encryptions are two-way. You can go from `x -> y`, and with some key go back `y -> x`.

Hashes (md5, sha256, etc.) are one-way. They can only go from `x -> y`, and there's no way to go backwards `y -> x`. There can be multiple values that reduce to the same hash (called collisions), where `md5(value1) -> x` AND `md5(value2) -> x`. This makes it impossible to determine what the original value was from a hash. 

[More reading for you][1]


  [1]: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1240852/is-it-possible-to-decrypt-md5-hashes
answers.title: How to decrypt multiple layered hash text from {md5, sha1, sha224, sha256, sha384, sha512}?

items.body_markdown:
The hash values are generated using a layer of hashing functions  is computed as: `h4(h3(h2(h1(â€˜textâ€²))))`, where the distinct hi â€™s come from the set `{md5, sha1, sha224, sha256, sha384, sha512}`. 

Note also that the hash values you see below are obtained after applying hexdigest on the output of each hi:



```
import base64

def sha512encryption(plain_text):
    return hashlib.sha512(plain_text.encode()).hexdigest()
```
This is example of python coding for sha512encryption. Similarly multiple layer of hashing is done.

Part **B** has been solved thanks to the inputs of @ScottCraner

    =IF(OR(ISNUMBER(SEARCH({"Assets","Revenues"},INDEX(F:F,MATCH(B3,G:G,0))))),1,-1)*SUMIFS(H:H,G:G,B3)

because we get "Assets" as the only result when we should get "Assets" and "Liabilities".

items.body_markdown:
I have a page with large number of drag and drop areas. There are about a hundred fields with a couple of images within which the user can sort images and there is also an option to drag and drop images from the file system of the computer. The images should only be sorted within their own fields while imports from the file system can land in any field.

I have been looking for a solution that makes the droppability of a field conditional. When the user starts dragging an image in one of the fields he shouldn't be able to drop it in the other fields. 

The closest I came is by making the e.preventDefault() function in the dragover event method conditional. It is only called when there is an external file or when an image is dragged within its own field. That works to the extend that a drop has no result when it is not desired. However, in situations where a drop is not allowed the cursor remains the same as when a drop is allowed.

As far as I can see the only way to get the "forbidden" cursor is to remove the dragover event method from the field. However, that would mean that each time I start dragging an image I need to remove the event method for the 99 fields that it is not in and each time I end the dragging I need to re-attach them. That seems rather inefficient.

Is there a better way to handle this?
items.title: How to selectively disable drop areas
